title: Introduction to Markdown and README files
text:
Using Markdown in GitHub - Tutorial






Important



GitHub Skills are systematically being updated to an issue-based workflow from the legacy README-based workflow. The following tutorial follows the updated issue-based workflow. If you began this exercise before 5-30-2025, your skills repository will look different from the current skills repository template. If this is the case, click here for the legacy README-based tutorial.


GitHub Skills: Communicate using markdown
We‚Äôll be using the Communicate Using Markdown Skills Tutorial to get some practice with markdown in GitHub. Follow along with the tutorial using your own GitHub account.

Step 1: Copy the exercise
Open the GitHub Skills link, and make sure you are logged into GitHub. Use the ‚ÄúCopy Exercise‚Äù button to make a new repository on your account:
When you open up the ‚ÄúCopy Exercise‚Äù link, you will be presented with the ‚ÄúCreate a new repository‚Äù interface. Keep all of the defaults, and click the green ‚ÄúCreate repository‚Äù button:







ImportantGitHub Skills tutorials use GitHub Actions in the background.



These actions use ‚Äúminutes‚Äù, which are limited in a private repository, but unlimited in a public one. We suggest keeping your GitHub Skills tutorial repositories public to avoid any minutes limitations.








TipYou‚Äôll notice that most steps in a GitHub Skills tutorial feature a message to wait about 20 seconds for the exercise to update.



GitHub Actions can take a little bit of time to run, so waiting this requisite time is important! Refresh the instructions after 20 seconds to make sure everything updates properly.




Step 2: Start the exercise
After waiting the suggested 20 seconds, refresh the repository, and click the ‚ÄúGo to Exercise‚Äù button in the README







Tip



I suggest moving the instructions tab into another window so you can work side-by-side with the instructions to limit switching back and forth between tabs. 




Step 3: Follow the exercise

Create a markdown file in a new branch
In this exercise, we will be using markdown to create an example ‚Äúblog‚Äù page. The content provided in the exercise is just an example; we can give a more personal touch to our own content.






Tip



During this tutorial, GitHub Skills will provide code blocks that you can copy directly to your clipboard to paste into the body of your Markdown document. But this defeats the purpose of getting practice with Markdown and building that muscle memory! Go ahead and type in your own content (don‚Äôt worry, it doesn‚Äôt have to match the example content perfectly)



On the Code tab of your repository, click the dropdown menu where it says ‚Äúmain‚Äù

In the ‚ÄúFind or create a branch‚Äù box, type start-blog and select ‚ÄúCreate branch start-blog from main‚Äù

Create a new file by clicking the ‚ÄúAdd file‚Äù button in your new branch (note this may look like a + symbol if you‚Äôre working in a condensed side-by-side view) and click ‚ÄúCreate new file‚Äù

Along the top of the dialogue box, name your file day-1.md

In your new file, create a level one heading to give the page a title

Add a couple level 2 headings for the names of each of the blog posts

Click the Preview tab in the top left of the dialogue box to view your rendered content

Click the ‚ÄúCommit changes‚Äù button in the top right and commit the changes directly to the start-blog branch




Make a list

Re-open the day-1.md file and click ‚ÄúEdit this file‚Äù

In the ## Morning Planning section, add a list of each type: unordered, ordered, and task








Note



GitHub skills only asks for a task list, but we want you to have practice with all list types; adding the other types will not mess up the GitHub Skills workflow, so go ahead and practice adding all three types!



Preview your content in the preview tab

Commit your changes directly to the start-blog branch




Add a code sample

After this commit, the day-1.md file should still be open. Click the ‚ÄúEdit this content‚Äù button to go back into editing mode

In the ‚ÄúReview‚Äù section, add a code chunk using the three backtick notation (it‚Äôs okay to use a different example than the one provided by GitHub Skills)

Preview your content

Commit your changes to the start-blog branch




Add an image

Open our day-1.md file in edit mode

Insert an image below the the ‚ÄúMorning Planning‚Äù level 2 heading. To make things a little more interesting, let‚Äôs use the Scubatocat image located at https://octodex.github.com/images/scubatocat.png

Preview your Markdown file

Go back to the Edit tab and replace the image with an HTML version that changes the size and position

Preview your updated image, and Commit changes to start-blog



Add some formatted text (off-script)
Before we finish up our tutorial, let‚Äôs add some formatted text. The GitHub Skills lesson does not mention anything about this, but it‚Äôs an important part of markdown that you should get some practice with!

Edit your day-1.md file one more time

Under the Daily Learning heading, add some bolded, italicized, and in-line code text

Preview your file, then commit your changes




Finish work: Merge your blog post
This step doesn‚Äôt have anything to do with markdown, but it‚Äôs good practice for working with Pull Requests from a branch!

Select the ‚ÄúPull requests‚Äù tab in the top navigation bar

Click the ‚ÄúCompare & pull request‚Äù button for start-blog

Click the ‚ÄúCreate pull request button‚Äù

Merge your pull request and confirm the merge
crumbs: Introduction to Markdown and README files

title: Introduction to Markdown and README files
text:
What about README files?
All of the things we did in this tutorial can be done in a README file! To illustrate this, we can copy the contents of our day-1.md file over to our README.md file in our Skills repository:

Navigate to the Code tab in the top navigation menu

Select day-1.md and switch to the Code view

Click the ‚ÄúCopy raw file‚Äù button at the top of the dialogue box (looks like two overlapping squares)

Navigate back to the Code tab, and edit the README file by clicking the ‚ÄúEdit file‚Äù button on the README

Replace the text in the dialogue box with the copied text from the day-1.md file

Commit your changes

Navigate back to the Code tab (this should bring you to the home page of our repository, and scroll down to see your markdown-formatted README file!
crumbs: Introduction to Markdown and README files

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Aims and Objectives
Project management is a key aspect to making workflows efficient and transparent on GitHub. GitHub Projects allow teams to plan and track work in a repository and across repositories. This skills session will use directed, interactive lessons to provide NOAA Fisheries staff with a foundation in using GitHub Projects to track, plan, and manage work on GitHub.

title: GitHub for Project Management
section: Prerequisites: What do I need before this workshop to follow along on my own?
text:
Prerequisites: What do I need before this workshop to follow along on my own?

This stand-alone skills session is meant for those with a basic understanding of Git and GitHub. Check out our Introduction to Git and GitHub lessons if you are new to Git and GitHub or need a refresher.
Projects in GitHub rely on GitHub Issues, so you may want to refresh yourself on issues with our Communicating in GitHub with Issues and Discussions lesson.

title: GitHub for Project Management
text: Project Management in GitHub

title: GitHub for Project Management
section: Tutorial: Getting familiar with GitHub Projects
text:
Tutorial: Getting familiar with GitHub Projects
For this tutorial, we‚Äôre going to be forking a demo repository (https://github.com/nmfs-opensci/GitHub-Clinic-demos), enabling Issues, and creating a Project. We will add some issues to our Project, and explore different project views and customization options to tailor our Projects to our specific needs. Follow along on your own account.

Step 1: Fork the repository






TipIf you have already forked this repository for a previous session, you can skip this step.



We have used this demo repository for previous GitHub Clinic demonstrations and tutorials, so you may already have a forked copy of this repository on your account. If you are unsure, you can search for [your-username]/GitHub-Clinic-demos in the GitHub search bar.



Open the demo repository in GitHub.

At the top of the repository, click the Fork button.

Keep everything default (your account should be listed under Owner, and the Repository name should be pre-filled for you). Click the green Create Fork button.

When you create your new fork, you may notice that the Issues tab that you normally see at the top of the repository is not there. We have to enable this in the repository settings. Navigate to the Settings tab in your forked repository. Scroll down to the Features section and check the box next to Issues. (Note that Projects is another option in the Features section; this should already be checked, but if it isn‚Äôt, go ahead and check that as well).




Step 2: Create a new Project
There are multiple ways to create projects in GitHub. Rather than being attached to one specific repository, Projects can act across any and all repositories in an account. Because of this functionality, Projects reside in either a user‚Äôs account or an organization‚Äôs account, rather than within a repository. We‚Äôre going to be creating a Project using the Projects tab within a repository, but keep in mind that we can access all of our Projects from our account home page.

Navigate to the Projects tab on the top ribbon bar of your repository. Click the green New project button to start a new project.

You will be presented with a number of pre-defined Project templates, each of which has a specific layout and customized configuration tailored to the type of planning or tracking your team may use. Feel free to explore these on your own; for now, let‚Äôs start a project from scratch. On the left-hand side of the pop-up, select the Table option under Start from scratch.

Give your new Project a name. Let‚Äôs call ours ‚ÄúGitHub Clinic example project‚Äù. Click the green Create project button to finalize your new project.

Let‚Äôs add a description and README to our project to describe our Project‚Äôs purpose. Click the ellipse button (View more options) at the top right of the project, and select Settings.

Add a short description and README to the Project to explain the purpose of the Project and how to use it. Note that the README supports markdown formatting. In future Projects, you may want to take advantage of this to flesh out the details of your Project and add more context.








NoteGitHub Projects default to Private visibility.



You may have noticed that there‚Äôs a padlock-style icon next to the title of our Project. This means that the Project is private, so only you and the people you specifically grant access can see the Project. We can change the visibility in this Settings menu as well. Sometimes it‚Äôs beneficial to make Projects publicly viewable for transparency purposes; otherwise, feel free to keep these Projects private. You can always add collaborators later.




Step 3: Add items to your project
Let‚Äôs populate our Project with some issues! We can add existing issues from any repository in the account (individual or organization) that the Project was created under. We can also create our own issues directly from the Project interface.


Let‚Äôs create a few example issues for our Project. Click the + button on the first line of the Project board, and click ‚ÄúCreate new issue‚Äù. This will pop up a dialogue box where we can add an issue to a repository. We‚Äôll create our issues in the GitHub Clinic Demo repository, so make sure the Repository section has the appropriate repository selected (Hint: click the Repository dropdown menu and type ‚Äúgithub-clinic-demos‚Äù in the search box).

I‚Äôve added some Issue templates for Bug report, Feature request, and Task to the demos repository that should transfer to your forked repository. Let‚Äôs add one of each type to our Project.








TipYou may need to pull changes from the parent repository to get the appropriate templates.



If you are working from a previously forked copy of the GitHub-Clinic-Demos repository, you will need to update your version of the repository with the parent repository hosted on nmfs-opensci. On the Code tab of your forked copy of the repository, there will be a banner saying your branch is behind the branch hosted on nmfs-opensci. Next to this banner, there should be a button called Sync fork. Go ahead and click that button, and select Update branch.




We can also add ‚Äúdraft‚Äù issues to our Project. These can be used as placeholders for items that may need to be more fleshed out or items that we don‚Äôt necessarily need as true ‚Äúissues‚Äù in a specific repository. Click in the Title spot below the last project item, and type in a draft issue.




Step 4: Adding fields
Let‚Äôs create some custom fields to better organize our project.

Iteration fields let us plan and track our work over repeating blocks of time. Iterations can be configured with customizable lengths and breaks to suit your team‚Äôs needs. Create an iteration field by clicking the + icon to the right of the Status column in our table view, and click ‚ÄúNew field‚Äù. Give your field a name, and change the field type to Iteration. You can customize when the iteration should start and how long each iteration should last.

Assign each of your Project items to an iteration. This will be useful when we explore the Roadmap layout later.

Let‚Äôs create a Priority field. Click the + icon to the right of the Iteration column in our table view, and click ‚ÄúNew field‚Äù. Name your field Priority, and select ‚ÄúSingle select‚Äù from the field type menu. Add options for Low, Medium, and High priority. Save your new field.

Assign each of your example issues to a priority level in your new field.




Step 5: Configure the Table layout
Let‚Äôs make this table a little more informative by adding some other fields.

Click the dropdown where it says View 1, and select the Fields menu. Under ‚ÄúHidden fields‚Äù, select Labels, Milestone, and Repository.

In the same dropdown, select the Group by option and select Priority to split the table by priority.

With the grouped view, we can now move items between priorities. Try this out by moving one of your items from medium to low priority. Do this by clicking and dragging from the number to the left of the issue title.


Change the name of your view by clicking the drop-down menu again and selecting Rename view. Let‚Äôs rename it to ‚ÄúPlanning‚Äù.

Save your changes to the view by clicking the green Save option in the dropdown menu.








CautionBe sure to save your view if you want to come back to it!



Views do not save to the project by default. If you make changes to a view that you want to be shown every time you open your project, be sure to save them. Otherwise, view changes will only be applied during the current session.




Step 6: Experiment with other views
Let‚Äôs create a couple new views to showcase the other view types. You‚Äôre welcome to play around with these views on your own, but for now we‚Äôll just introduce the other view types.

Create a new view by clicking the + New view tab at the top of the project. Select the Board option.

Rename this view to ‚ÄúProgress Board‚Äù, and click the green Save button to save your view. Here we can move issues between different categories. The default is a traditional kanban-style board with statuses for level of completeness. However, we can also add different categories to assign and organize issues to whatever is needed. We can even add multiple versions of these boards to categorize items in different ways.

Now let‚Äôs add a timeline view. Select + New view at the top of the project, and select the Roadmap option.

GitHub will prompt us that we need a date field set for this view. Recall that we set up an Iteration field earlier in the exercise called Weekly deadline. Choose the Weekly deadline start option for the Start date and Weekly deadline end option for the Target date.

Rename this view to Timeline and save your view.

Feel free to experiment with the different view types and features available with Projects. Check out GitHub‚Äôs documentation for Projects (be sure to look at the different sub-pages on the right-hand side of the page) for more information, tips, and tricks about GitHub Projects.

title: Workflows in Git and GitHub
text:
Aims and Objectives
Developing a project in Git and GitHub can be messy, especially when collaborating within a team. Overlapping commits can lead to merge conflicts and a convoluted commit history. Establishing a consistent branch-based workflow can help alleviate these concerns. This skills session will use directed, interactive lessons to provide NOAA Fisheries staff with a foundation in using branching strategies to streamline project development and tailor it to your team‚Äôs size and needs.

title: Workflows in Git and GitHub
section: Prerequisites: What do I need before this workshop to follow along on my own?
text:
Prerequisites: What do I need before this workshop to follow along on my own?

This stand-alone skills session is meant for those with a basic understanding of Git and GitHub. Check out our Introduction to Git and GitHub lessons if you are new to Git and GitHub or need a refresher.
Git workflows are based around the concept of branching. If you are not familiar with branches, be sure to take a look at our Branches and Pull Requests lesson.

title: Workflows in Git and GitHub
section: Git Workflows for Development and Collaboration
text: Git Workflows for Development and Collaboration

title: Workflows in Git and GitHub
text:
Tutorial: Practice with Workflows
GitHub Skills: Create a release-based workflow
We‚Äôll be using the Create a Release-based Workflow Skills Tutorial to practice using a GitHub Flow-style workflow with releases. Follow along with the tutorial using your own GitHub account.

Step 1: Start the course
Open the GitHub Skills link, and make sure you are logged into GitHub. Use the ‚ÄúStart course‚Äù button to make a new repository on your account:

When you open up the ‚ÄúStar‚Äù link, you will be presented with the ‚ÄúCreate a new repository‚Äù interface. Keep all of the defaults, and click the green ‚ÄúCreate repository‚Äù button:







ImportantGitHub Skills tutorials use GitHub Actions in the background.



These actions use ‚Äúminutes‚Äù, which are limited in a private repository, but unlimited in a public one. We suggest keeping your GitHub Skills tutorial repositories public to avoid any minutes limitations.








TipYou‚Äôll notice that most steps in a GitHub Skills tutorial feature a message to wait about 20 seconds for the exercise to update.



GitHub Actions can take a little bit of time to run, so waiting this requisite time is important! Refresh the instructions after 20 seconds to make sure everything updates properly.




Step 2: Start the exercise
After waiting the suggested 20 seconds, refresh the repository, and click the ‚ÄúGo to Exercise‚Äù button in the README






Tip



I suggest moving the instructions tab into another window so you can work side-by-side with the instructions to limit switching back and forth between tabs.





Step 3: Follow the exercise

Create a beta release
In this exercise, we will be creating a release-based workflow that is built on the foundations of GitHub flow.

Go to the Releases page for the repository. If you are in a condensed view mode, this link will be at the bottom of the Code page. If you‚Äôre viewing in a full-sized window, this page will be in the sidebar on the right-hand side of the repository window on the Code page.

Click the green Create a new release button to start a new new release

Click the Tag: Select tag dropdown, and specify a release number. Use v0.9 for this example. Click Create new tag: v0.9 on publish.

Give the release a title, and an optional short description. Check the box next to Set as a pre-release.

Click the green Publish release button to finalize your pre-release.




Introduce a bug to be fixed later
Next, we‚Äôll add a bug to our code that will be fixed later in this tutorial.

At the top of the repository, click on the Pull requests tab and click the green New button (if you‚Äôre in the full window view, this will say New pull request).

Set the base: dropdown menu to release-v1.0 and the compare: dropdown menu to update-text-colors, and click the green Create pull request button.
Update the pull request title to ‚ÄúUpdated game text style‚Äù. Optionally add a more detailed description to your pull request. Click the green Create pull request button.

Merge the pull request, wait about 20 seconds for the instructions to refresh, and refresh the instructions README page.





Add a new feature to the release branch
We‚Äôll be using the release-v1.0 branch to add features to our repository. We can treat this branch as a long-lived but ephemeral branch in the spirit of GitHub Flow.

In the Code tab, create a new branch off of the main branch. This will be our ‚Äúfeature‚Äù branch. Name your branch feature-background.

Open the base.css file, and click the ‚Äúedit this file‚Äù button (it should look like a pen in the upper right hand corner of the code chunk. Scroll down to line 109. In the body declaration, add a line that changes the background color to black using the background-color: black; line as shown in the tutorial.

Commit your changes, updating the commit message to be more descriptive.

Navigate to the Pull requests tab, and create a new pull request. Set the base branch to release-v1.0 and the compare branch to feature-background. Click the green Create pull request button, and fill in the pull request template. Click the Create pull request button to finalize the pull request.

Merge the pull request and delete your feature branch.

Wait about 20 seconds for GitHub Actions to update, then refresh the instructions README page.



Open a release pull request
Opening a pull request early in the release can help facilitate discussion about the release. Any commits added to the compare branch after opening the pull request will be associated with that pull request until it‚Äôs closed.

In the Pull requests tab, open a new pull request with base: main and compare: release-v1.0. You can do this from the ‚Äúrelease-v1.0 had recent pushes‚Äù banner to save time.

Add some detail to your pull request body description, and click the green Create pull request button. Don‚Äôt merge your pull request yet!

Wait 20 seconds for GitHub Actions to update, then refresh the instructions README page.



Generate release notes and merge
You can generate release notes automatically based on the content of your pull request. Let‚Äôs practice this with our ‚ÄúRelease v1.0‚Äù pull request.

Navigate to the Releases page from the Code tab of your repository (see above if you need a reminder of how to get there).
Click the Draft a new release button in the top right corner.

In the Tag: dropdown menu, type v1.0.0, and create a tag with that name. Change the Target: dropdown to select the release-v1.0 branch.

Click the Generate release notes button at the top of the description box.

Review your release notes and make any changes if necessary.

Set the Target: branch back to main (we only needed the release branch to generate our release notes).

Click the Save draft button (not the Publish release button; we‚Äôll publish in the next step).

Open your Release v1.0 pull request on the Pull requests tab.

Merge your pull request.

Wait 20 seconds for the GitHub Actions to update, then refresh the instructions page.



An aside on semantic versioning
This release workflow uses a system called semantic versioning, which is a convention for specifying compatibility. It uses a three-part version number: major version, minor version, and patch.



Finalize the release

From the Code page, navigate to the Releases page. Click the edit button next to your v1.0.0 release.

Ensure the Target branch is set to main

Scroll to the bottom of the page, and click Publish release.

Wait 20 seconds for the GitHub actions to update, then refresh the instructions README page.



Commit a hotfix to the release
We can make a short-lived, ephemeral branch to fix a bug. The tutorial has already introduced a bug (we did this in the first part of the tutorial), and created a feature branch (fix-game-background) and a hotfix release branch (hotfix-v1.0.1) for us that fixes the bug. Let‚Äôs make a pull request to introduce this bug fix into our repo.

In the Pull requests tab, open a pull request setting hotfix-v1.0.1 as the base branch and fix-game-background as the compare branch.

Add a description to the pull request body, and change the title of the pull request to ‚ÄúHotfix for broken game style‚Äù. Create your pull request and merge it into our hotfix-v1.0.1 release branch.

Open a new pull request with main as the base branch and hotfix-v1.0.1 as the compare branch.

Add a detailed description to the pull request body.

Create and merge your pull request into the main branch.

Wait 20 seconds for GitHub Actions to update, then refresh the README.



Create release v1.0.1
The final step is incorporating our hotfix changes into a new release to distribute to the necessary channels.

Navigate to the Releases page from the Code tab, and click the Draft a new release button.

Set the Target branch to main and add a v1.0.1 tag to follow semantic versioning. Click Generate release notes to auto-populate the release title and notes. Review the release notes, and customize if desired.

Click Publish release at the bottom of the page. Wait 20 more seconds for the tutorial README to update, then refresh the instructions.

You‚Äôre finished with the tutorial! Now that you have practiced with a release-based workflow, feel free to experiment with other workflows and select the one that works best for your project and team.

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
What are GitHub Actions?

Automate, customize, and execute software, package, and report development workflows in your repository
Workflows are made up of individual tasks called actions
Supports CI/CD, automation, and more

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Core Concepts
GitHub Actions is built around a few key concepts:

Workflows: Automated processes that you can set up in your repository.
Events: Specific activities that trigger a workflow (e.g., a push or a pull request).
Jobs: A set of steps that execute on the same runner.
Steps: An individual task that can run commands or an action.
Actions: A standalone command that‚Äôs combined into steps to create a job. Actions are the smallest portable building block of a workflow.
Runners: A server that runs your workflows when they‚Äôre triggered.

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Anatomy of a Workflow File
Workflows are defined in YAML files located in the .github/workflows/ directory of your repository.
name: Simple Workflow

on: [push]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Check out repository code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Greet the world
        run: echo "Hello, world!"

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Events (on)
An event is a specific activity in a repository that triggers a workflow run.

push: When code is pushed to a branch.
pull_request: When a pull request is opened, updated, or closed.
schedule: Run at a scheduled time (using cron syntax).
workflow_dispatch: Manual trigger from the GitHub UI.

‚Ä¶and many more!
# Run on pushes to the main branch
on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Jobs & Runners
A workflow run is made up of one or more jobs.

Jobs run in parallel by default.
You can configure jobs to run sequentially using needs.
Each job runs in a fresh virtual environment on a runner.

You specify the runner type with runs-on:
jobs:
  my_first_job:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
  my_second_job:
    runs-on: windows-latest

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Steps, Actions, and Commands
A job contains a sequence of steps.

uses: Specifies an action to run. Actions are reusable units of code. You can find thousands on the GitHub Marketplace.
run: Executes command-line programs using the runner‚Äôs shell.

steps:
  # Use a pre-built action from the marketplace
  - uses: actions/checkout@v4

  # Run a command
  - name: Install dependencies
    run: npm install

  # Run another command
  - name: Run tests
    run: npm test

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Use Cases
What can you automate with GitHub Actions?

Continuous Integration (CI): Automatically build and test your code on every push.
Continuous Deployment (CD): Automatically deploy your application to the cloud.
Issue Triage: Label and comment on new issues automatically.
Notifications: Send a message to Slack or Discord when a build fails.
Scheduled Tasks: Run a script to check for broken links on your site every night.

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Pre-built Actions

GitHub Marketplace provides a collection of pre-built actions for many tasks
Many software packages offer their own pre-built actions (e.g., Quarto actions, GitHub Actions for R)
Contribute your own actions for others to use

title: Automating Workflows with GitHub Actions
text:
Security Best Practices

Use least privilege for tokens and secrets.
Avoid hardcoding sensitive data.
Use GITHUB_TOKEN for authentication.
Review third-party actions for security.

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
text:
What is a Branch?

Separate workspace where you can make changes and try new ideas without affecting main project
Isolated, contained development area
Add content to a repository without affecting other code
Can be created from any other branch

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
text: What is a Branch?

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
text:
Why use branches?

Allows multiple users to contribute to project without interfering with each other
Fix a bug or add a feature without breaking the main project
Experiment with new ideas without affecting the main project

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
section: How are branches different from forks?
text:
How are branches different from forks?

Housed within the repository, rather than across copies of the repository
Collaborating and project management within a team, rather than outside the team
Switching between branches changes the repository structure, rather than switching to a different repository

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
text:
The process of branching

Create a branch on a repository you have write access to
Make and commit your changes, making commits along the way if necessary
If necessary/desired, sync any changes made from the main branch to your branch
Create a pull request to contribute your changes back to the parent repository
Resolve merge conflicts, if necessary

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
section: Things to keep in mind when branching
text:
Things to keep in mind when branching

Branches can be ephemeral or permanent
Branches can have separate read/write access from each other

title: Branches and Pull Requests in Git and GitHub
text:
Pull requests

Proposal to merge changes from a branch (or fork) into another
Slight misnomer; ‚Äúpull‚Äù is more like ‚Äúpush‚Äù or ‚Äúmerge‚Äù in this respect
Initiates a conversation between the requester and collaborators
Review and discuss changes prior to merging

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
What is GitHub Enterprise?

An account with GitHub organizations (orgs) that has more controls than GitHub Free.
Your personal GitHub account can have repos in GitHub Free orgs or GitHub Enterprise orgs.
Your identity (username) does not change ‚Äì as long as your user account uses your noaa.gov email.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise different?

It is controlled by work and has more rules
It requires CAC sign-in - more secure
It requires a license.
Outside (non NOAA) collaborators have to be added by an admin to repos. They use a license if the repo is private or internal

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise different?

GitHub 3rd party applications require approval
More features: private and internal GitHub Pages, more GitHub Action minutes, bigger files allowed.
Allows internal repositories only visible to NMFS GitHub users across GHEC. See code from other science centers (if they made it internal)
Collaborate on repos with any other NMFS GHEC org. You can be on orgs at other centers

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise different?

Has IT managed automatic backups.
NMFS doesn‚Äôt lose code due to repo owner leaving NOAA
FedRAMP approved unlike GitHub free

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
section: How is GitHub Enterprise not different?
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise not different?

You can create repos just like in GitHub Free
You have access to the usual collaboration tools: projects, GitHub Actions, GitHub Pages
You are admin on your own repos and can admin them as usual‚Ä¶except re outside collaborators.

title: GitHub Pages
text:
What is GitHub Pages?

Turn your repository into a website
Share your project, resume, portfolio, documentation, or even a blog with the world
Takes content from main branch and publishes to a website

title: GitHub Pages
text:
Why use GitHub Pages?

Easy and free way to publish content
Can make internal, private web-pages with GHEC
In NMFS:

Make a sleek web-hosted lab manual
Share reports in HTML
Make a landing page for a lab or program

title: GitHub Pages
section: How to turn on GitHub Pages
text:
How to turn on GitHub Pages
Access GitHub Pages in the Settings menu under Code and automation

title: GitHub Pages
section: How to turn on GitHub Pages
text:
How to turn on GitHub Pages
Make sure Source is set to ‚ÄúDeploy from a branch‚Äù
Select the branch to deploy from (usually this is main)

title: GitHub Pages
section: How to turn on GitHub Pages
text:
How to turn on GitHub Pages
Select the folder to deploy from (/(root) is the main directory of the repository)
Save your changes

title: GitHub Pages
text:
How GitHub Pages recognizes content

A GitHub Pages ‚Äúaction‚Äù runs after every commit
Any HTML file in the source directory is indexed and can be linked to
Any Markdown file will be rendered and indexed
But not Quarto‚Ä¶

Need to render to HTML first
GitHub Actions can help us with this

title: GitHub Pages
text:
Theming a basic page
Add a file called _config.yml to your repository
Add the line theme: jekyll-theme-slate to your file

title: GitHub Pages
text:
Theming a basic page
Add a file called _config.yml to your repository
Add the line theme: jekyll-theme-slate to your file

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
What is Markdown?

Lightweight markup language for formatting elements to plain-text text documents
Used by GitHub in a variety of places

README files
Issues and comments
Discussions
Commit messages

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Why use Markdown?

Lightweight - doesn‚Äôt balloon file sizes
Portable - makes it easy to share formatted documents across platforms
Adaptable - Quarto, Jupyter Notebooks, RMarkdown
Ubiquitous - Used across a number of websites and applications

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Headings

Created using the # symbol
Number of # corresponds to the level of header

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Text styling

Bold - **bold text**
Italics - *italicized text*
Bold italics - ***bold and italicized text***
Superscript - superscript^2^
Subscript - superscript~2~
Strikethrough - ~~strikethrough~~
Code (monospace) - `code`

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Code blocks
Code blocks are denoted by a series of three back-ticks:
```
x = 1 + 1
print('Hello, world!')
```
x = 1 + 1
print('Hello, world!')
You can style code chunks based on the language
``` r
x = 1 + 1
print('Hello, world!')
```
x = 1 + 1
print('Hello, world!')

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Lists

Ordered lists
Number or letter followed by period and two spaces

first
second


Unordered lists
Dash or asterisk followed by a space

Unordered list item
Unordered list item

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Checklists
Special markdown for GitHub
Dash followed by a space, closed brackets ([]), and another space
- [] Checklist 1
- [] Checklist 2

title: Intro to Markdown
text:
Links and Images

Links
Follow the notation
[text to show](link to content)
This is a link to the schedule

Images
Follow the notation
![Caption](path to image "alt text")



Look at this scubatocat!

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
What are GitHub Projects?

Adaptable, flexible tool for planning and tracking work on GitHub
Spreadsheet, task-board, and roadmap integrated with issues and pull requests
Provide multiple views by filtering, sorting, grouping issues/PRs
Visualize work with configurable charts
Add custom fields to track team-specific metadata

title: GitHub for Project Management
section: Why use GitHub for project management?
text:
Why use GitHub for project management?

Issues and projects stoke collaboration
Issues act as short-term to-do lists
Projects capture longer-term goals and organize short-term issues

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Project views
Table layout - Excel-style spreadsheet of project issues and metadata

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Project views
Board layout - Kanban-style board for organizing issues by status or label

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Project views
Roadmap layout- High-level visualization of project over time

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Adding views

You can have multiple views in one project
Views can be tailored to many different needs through layouts, fields, and filters
Views can be temporary for a single session or saved to the project

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
What is Git?



Program to track file changes and create a history of those changes
Creates a ‚Äòcontainer‚Äô for a set of files called a repository

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
What is GitHub?



Collaborative software designed to organize files and track changes by different people through time
Built on top of Git
Allows to sync (clone) Git repositories locally and over the web

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Why use Git and GitHub?

Version control - for you and others
Collaboration - within your team and among colleagues and peers outside of your team
Project management - collaborative ‚Äúto-do‚Äù lists
Publishing platform - README files and GitHub Pages
